description: Borrowed from Middle French perdu, originally after sentinelle perdue.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, military) Stationed in an exposed or hazardous position; hidden in ambush. Originally as sentinel perdu. [17th–19th c.]
(now rare) In a dangerous situation; lost, desperate. [from 17th c.]
examples: Among certain grizzled sea-gossips of the gun decks and forecastle went a rumor perdue  […]

entries.meaning: (now rare) Hidden; concealed from sight. Chiefly with lie. [from 17th c.]
examples: He should lie Perdue who is to walk the round.

entries.meaning: One placed on watch, or in ambush.
A soldier sent on a forlorn hope.
